entries.fullText: Theodore Caldwell came from California- Sister Gula fails every day -- have devoted this day to her [?] [?] -
entries.summaryText: Theodore Caldwell visited from California and spent the day with Sister Gula who is not doing well.

entries.fullText:
Rain
Sister Mary took care
of Sister Gula , I went
down town to see
VanVhooris & Judge
Selden about my trial
pamphlet
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to see VanVhooris and Judge Selden about her trial pamphlet.

entries.fullText: Went to Unitarian Church
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the Unitarian Church.

entries.fullText:
Rhoda De [Gar?] died at 10.30
this A.M - Mother & self called
Uncle Elias sad enough -
blind & almost totally deaf -
Sister Gula very tired
& suffering
entries.summaryText: Rhoda De [Gar?] died and Susan B. Anthony visited Uncle Elias and Sister Gula.

entries.fullText:
Aunt Sophia McLean
here to dinner - Gula
Brighter then rested - but
all tired out
entries.summaryText: Aunt Sophia McLean visited and Sister Gula was feeling better.

entries.fullText:
Aunt Esther McLean
& daughter Melissa to
tea - Aunt Esther
spent night - Gula saw
them for a few minutes -
entries.summaryText: Aunt Esther McLean and daughter Melissa visited and stayed the night, Sister Gula saw them briefly.

entries.fullText:
Funeral of Rhoda De Garmo
Aunt Esther attended
with Mother & self - I
hope appreciated being
acceptably - the sleep, of
death in faith of life is
beautiful indeed
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the funeral of Rhoda De Garmo with Aunt Esther and Mother.

entries.fullText: Telegram from brother D.A. inquiring after Sister Gula-
entries.summaryText: Brother D.A. inquires about Sister Gula.

entries.fullText: No entry
entries.summaryText: No entry

entries.fullText: Attended Unitarian church
entries.summaryText: Attended Unitarian church.

entries.fullText: Nephew Arthur Mosher arrived this evig from Leavenworth
entries.summaryText: Nephew Arthur Mosher arrives from Leavenworth.

entries.fullText: No entry
entries.summaryText: No entry

entries.fullText: Dr. Henry [?] arrive at 10 & left at 10 P.M. - but it was a comfort to Sister Gula to see him - Gula rode out with Aaron & Mary
entries.summaryText: Dr. Henry arrives and leaves, Sister Gula rides out with Aaron and Mary.

entries.fullText:
Friday, 26 Sister Mary took
care of sister
Gula this night- the second night
Aaron has left her-Gula took
her last ride this day

I stayed up until 2 A.M.
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary took care of Sister Gula while Aaron was away.

entries.fullText:
Sister Gula had severe
attack like croup in P.M.
While George & Maggie were here-
Aaron went for Dr. [?]
- this was last day Gula was
dressed
entries.summaryText: Sister Gula had a severe attack while visitors were present and Aaron went to get a doctor.

entries.fullText:
Mary up this night
Sister Gula in bed
all day- very feeble-
but no more of those
spasmodic attacks-
entries.summaryText: Sister Gula was in bed all day and was feeble but did not have any more spasmodic attacks.

entries.fullText:
I stayed up this night - 2-
Sister up an hour in
P.M. with dress on-
letter from Mrs. Stanton-
first in long weeks & months
Dr. [ ?] called-
entries.summaryText: The author stayed up late and received a letter from Mrs. Stanton, the first in a long time. A doctor also called.

entries.fullText:
weather beautiful
Mary's night
Sister Gula Sat up an hour in P.M.
Maggie took Piano away- it just broke
me down- the lack of feeling for May & self- Law makes the husband & child
possesors of all things material- but the
spiritual still belongs to the sisters & mother &
that breaking up to us is quite equal to my
Sister May took care of Gula until 4-
no right with Gula
entries.summaryText: Susan writes about the lack of feeling for May and herself, and how the law makes the husband and child possessors of all things material.

entries.fullText:
Women Tax Payers meeting-
did not attend- took a
sleep instead- to be ready
for the night- Gula sat up
an hour in [?] - Parker
Pillsbury to tea & left on 10 P.M. train
for Salem, O.- Billeys Perine to tea
went to Depot with P.P.- May's night
with [?] Gula
entries.summaryText: Susan did not attend the Women Tax Payers meeting and instead took a nap. Parker Pillsbury came over for tea and left for Salem, O. Billeys Perine also came over for tea and went to the depot with Parker Pillsbury.

entries.fullText:
Letter from Mrs. Stanton
tells of Bob's having hip disease-
Arthur returned from
New York & Boston

My night with Gula
entries.summaryText: Susan received a letter from Mrs. Stanton about Bob's hip disease. Arthur returned from New York and Boston. Susan spent the night with Gula.

entries.fullText:
Sent letters to May
Ann McLean & D.R. &
Merritt- Sister Gula has
one long weary struggle
by day & by night - only the
anodyne brings any [?]
of rest even-
entries.summaryText: Susan sent letters to May, Ann McLean, D.R., and Merritt. Sister Gula is struggling and only the anodyne brings any rest.

entries.fullText:
Did not go out-
one week to day since
Gula was dressed-
up to this- she has lain
in her bedroom- since she gone
up- before that-on the sofa
mainly during the days
entries.summaryText: Susan did not go out. It has been one week since Gula was dressed and she has been mainly on the sofa during the days.

entries.fullText:
Gula had two fainting
turns in A.M.- she
then said her bed must
be moved into parlor-
& it was in the P.M.
& she & all of us felt
it so much more
comfortable
entries.summaryText: Gula had two fainting turns in the morning and then said her bed must be moved into the parlor, which was done in the afternoon and everyone felt it was more comfortable.

entries.fullText:
Abraham Meir of
Centre Falls spent night here
entries.summaryText: Abraham Meir of Centre Falls spent night here

entries.fullText:
Nephew Arthur left
for Leavenworth at 10 A.M.,
May McLean Maxwell
dined at Maggie's & called
here- Mrs. Baker dined
with us & had satisfactory
talk with Sister Gula-
entries.summaryText: Nephew Arthur left for Leavenworth, May McLean Maxwell dined at Maggie's & called here, Mrs. Baker dined with us & had satisfactory talk with Sister Gula

entries.fullText:
S.D. Porter read
& prayed with Gula-
Mrs. Sam. Hamliton
& Mrs. D.Dewey called-
entries.summaryText: S.D. Porter read & prayed with Gula, Mrs. Sam. Hamliton & Mrs. D.Dewey called

entries.fullText:
[?] Rev. Celia Burleigh at Unitarian
Church- oneness with God- Sister Mary- Rev. A.
J. Chapin, Universalist Church.
- called Rev. Montgomery's to see Chapin
-Magie & Aaron staid with Gula-
she had sad day- falling into a
sort of stupor- [S.A. Porter]
[called -read & prayed with Gula]
entries.summaryText: Rev. Celia Burleigh at Unitarian Church- oneness with God- Sister Mary- Rev. A. J. Chapin, Universalist Church. Called Rev. Montgomery's to see Chapin. Magie & Aaron staid with Gula. She had sad day- falling into a sort of stupor- [S.A. Porter] [called -read & prayed with Gula]

entries.fullText:
Mary Dobbin returned
to work- Lizzie
left-- Little T.R. quite ill
Mother very severe cold-
Mrs. Benjamin called & bid
Gula good bye- Maggie
came up a few minutes, not
Harry- little T.R. very sick
entries.summaryText: Mary Dobbin returned to work, Lizzie left, Little T.R. quite ill, Mother very severe cold, Mrs. Benjamin called and bid Gula goodbye, Maggie came up for a few minutes, not Harry, little T.R. very sick.

entries.fullText:
Hannah had her
fingers all cracked again
took ether- Little T.R.
very sick- Lung inflammation
Maggie not up to an hour here
First Women Congress in New York
entries.summaryText: Hannah had her fingers all cracked again, took ether, Little T.R. very sick with lung inflammation, Maggie not up to an hour here, First Women Congress in New York.

entries.fullText:
Gula had a little less
uncomfortable day- Letter from
Sister Annie & Brother Daniel.
Little Susie been quite ill - T.R. & I
word to & of Gula [?] [?] &
true feeling- Mary Baker Slocum
returned to Sister Hannahs
called at Registry office &
found my name registered-
entries.summaryText: Gula had a little less uncomfortable day, received a letter from Sister Annie and Brother Daniel, Little Susie has been quite ill, T.R. and I spoke to and of Gula, Mary Baker Slocum returned to Sister Hannah's, called at Registry office and found my name registered.

entries.fullText:
Women Tax Payers meeting
I attended- Amy Post tried to
register again- but was denied-
Niece Maggie staid with Gula
entries.summaryText: Attended Women Tax Payers meeting, Amy Post tried to register again but was denied, Niece Maggie stayed with Gula.

entries.fullText:
Gula seems very weak-
It is wonderful- the slow
but sure decay, day by day-
The Telegraph reports
well if the Woman's Congress
-- I was not invited to
sign the call- nor attend
the Congress-
entries.summaryText: Gula seems very weak, it is wonderful - the slow but sure decay, day by day. The Telegraph reports well if the Woman's Congress - I was not invited to sign the call nor attend the Congress.

entries.fullText:
Got letters from
Mrs Stanton & Mrs
Blake relative to
Women's Congress & my
not being invited
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives letters from Mrs. Stanton and Mrs. Blake regarding the Women's Congress and her not being invited.

entries.fullText:
3 reasons-
1st my name began with A
and must come at head
of signers to call
2nd - they would have to give
me my title & that made
[?] W.S.
of which I am their President
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives three reasons why she was not invited to the Women's Congress.

entries.fullText:
at 3rd - [ If ?] they let
one in, [they] D could
not be [?] -
too [?]
Mrs. Livermore is Mrs. Hooker
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony mentions Mrs. Livermore and Mrs. Hooker in her journal entry.

entries.fullText:
Cal. [?] lecture
for W. T. P Association
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a lecture in Cal. for the W. T. P Association.

entries.fullText: Called to See Mrs. I de Le [?] of Toledo at the [?] her brother in [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Mrs. I de Le in Toledo.

entries.fullText: Gula had her first satisfactory talk of future with A. this A.M.
entries.summaryText: Gula had a positive conversation about her future with someone named A.

entries.fullText: Aunt Sophia McLean & son Ellison here to dinner - In getting out of Omnibus on arriving home - she slipped & could not walk for months
entries.summaryText: Aunt Sophia McLean and her son Ellison had dinner with Susan B. Anthony and Aunt Sophia had an accident getting out of the Omnibus.

entries.fullText: Mrs M. Joslyn Gage lecture The U. S. on trial not S.B.A. Small audience - an able lecture
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended a lecture by Mrs. M. Joslyn Gage about the United States.

entries.fullText: Mrs G. called in A.M. - Sarah Owen took me to ride in P.M. Sister Gula looks very badly - it does not seem possible that she can endure much longer
entries.summaryText: Mrs. G visited in the morning and Sarah Owen took Susan B. Anthony for a ride in the afternoon. Gula's health is deteriorating.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. E.C. Stanton's lecture
before women's tax payers-
she, Mrs. Gage callen in A.M.-
- I called on them at Mrs.L.C. Smith
in P.M.- the rest of the girls went
to lecture & I staid home- sister Gula
still lower & lower-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a lecture by Mrs. E.C. Stanton and visits Mrs. Gage and sister Gula.

entries.fullText:
Ground white with snow
-staid up till 1 last night-
Death marches slowly but surely-
at noon to-day- it seemed as if
the end had come- chiking
from phlegm- unable to raise it-
Maggie here all day- sent for Dr. S.
at 6- said she might die any hour & might live
tow or three days-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes the snow and the illness of Maggie.

entries.fullText:
From this date two of us
staid with Gula every night-
Maggie & I the first half- & Mary
& Aaron the last-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes taking turns staying with Gula every night.

entries.fullText:
Gula called for glass to look
at herself- said death is stamped on
my face- in her agony of weakness
she [?]of if I could only go to sleep
& never wake again- but I must be
patient to the end" then "what will you
do with me"-

It seemed every hour must
end the ineffable suffering [?] but
night- & all this day the same Aaron
never left the house- Mr. Porter called at
noon- - at 11 A.M. I offered my vote
again - S.Lewis the tool to deny & tell me
my name had been struck from Register-
Letters from Gage & Stanton of call
for Washington Convention-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes Gula's deteriorating health and her own political activities.

entries.fullText:
It seemed every hour must
end the ineffable suffering [?] but
night- & all this day the same Aaron
never left the house- Mr. Porter called at
noon- - at 11 A.M. I offered my vote
again - S.Lewis the tool to deny & tell me
my name had been struck from Register-
Letters from Gage & Stanton of call
for Washington Convention-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes Gula's suffering and her own political activities.

entries.fullText:
It is perfectly dreadful- the
struggle to get out of this body- Gula
about the same- only weaker and weaker
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes Gula's struggle and declining health.

entries.fullText:
Women Tax Payers meeting- did
not attend- these days cover
us with a fearful night-mare
feeling- nothing but the cry of "How long'
Oh how long must this suffering continue
& all of us [?] hopeless to relieve
gave no anodyne this night- the suffering
all realized most [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not attend a Women Tax Payers meeting and expresses her frustration with the current state of affairs.

entries.fullText:
Gave Sister Gula no anodyne
last night nor during this day- and such
a restless 24 hours- such suffering-every
breath a groan. Telegram at 7 P.M.
from T.A. Sister May Luther there & all eving
[?] next week-- At six this evng we
were all glad to give anodyne again & she
had a less suffering night- So Maggie slept till
[?] [?] got up-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony tends to Sister Gula's suffering and gives her an anodyne to help her sleep.

entries.fullText:
Gula under influence of anodyne
since 7 last night- oblivious to all pain-
but dreadfully distressed look- ate virtually
nothing, a fine with ten spoonfuls gruel
& rice water-- Maggie & self the part of
night-- She said it is wonderful her
long life can hold out when all
is gone

rained all day-
entries.summaryText: Sister Gula is under the influence of an anodyne and is not feeling pain, but is distressed and not eating much. Susan B. Anthony and Maggie tend to her throughout the night.

entries.fullText:
Dear Sister Gulema passed
away at 5.30 this A.M.- so easily & softly as
hardly to be seen- Sister Mary alone at her
side. Sisters Hannah & May & niece
Maggie & self- performed the last sad
offices ourselves- then Mary Hallowell
came & spent day- Mr & Mrs. Sackett
left our sofas in bedroom & back parlor
entries.summaryText: Sister Gulema passes away and Susan B. Anthony and her sisters perform the last rites. Mary Hallowell comes to visit and Mr. and Mrs. Sackett leave.

entries.fullText:
Our oldest sister gone
-3 of us left & two brothers
- what a break in our circle
Hannah & May slept on sofas
until 1 then Wendell taken ill- &
Hannah called- so I went down
& laid on bedroom sofa-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony reflects on the loss of her oldest sister and tends to her brother Wendell who has fallen ill.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary Luther &
Jannie came out at 5 P.M. and
Dr. M. & Annie & little D.R. &
Susie D. at 9 P.M.- all
here but Merritt- we have
never all been together
in over 20 years-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's family members come to visit, including Sister Mary Luther, Jannie, Dr. M., Annie, little D.R., and Susie D. Merritt is the only one who is not present.

entries.fullText: In this city, on the morning of the 9th inst., after a long and weary sickness, Guelma Penn, wife of Aaron M. McLean, and eldest daughter of the late Daniel Anthony. Notice of funeral hereafter
entries.summaryText: Guelma Penn, eldest daughter of the late Daniel Anthony, passed away in McLEAN after a long sickness. Funeral details to be announced later.

entries.fullText:
Funeral at 2 P.M.
J. H. K. McLean & new wife
Amy- and DeWitt McLean -
cousin Hannah Hathaway & cousin
Marie came - Rev D.K. Ortled
spoke most unsatisfactorally -
(Dear Gulas poor face Spoke of rest
eternal beyond)
entries.summaryText: Funeral and visit from family and Rev. D.K. Ortled, who spoke unsatisfactorily.

entries.fullText:
May Luther & Darius left for
Kingston at 7:30 -
Brother D.A. for Kansas
at 10 P.M. - all dined at
Sister Hannah's -
Sister Annie & children
Dr. Henry & wife left at 9 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Family members leave for Kingston and Kansas, dinner at Sister Hannah's.

entries.fullText:
Aaron & DeWitt dined at
niece Maggie'S - cousin Almira
left at 9 P.M. - Brother Aaron
prevailed as DeWitt to stop over
until Monday --
entries.summaryText: Aaron and DeWitt dine at niece Maggie's, cousin Almira leaves, and Aaron convinces DeWitt to stay until Monday.

entries.fullText:
Aaron & DeWitt
went to Niagara Falls on
10 A.M. train & back at 6 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Aaron and DeWitt visit Niagara Falls.

entries.fullText:
Sister Annie & DeWitt went to
lunch with Maggie & George dinner(?)
Mr S D Porter called-
he said particularly on me - for my
? donation this sermon to my sister
- we talked over many points
of Bartlett's say sister Gula had been
in a state of rebellion against [?]
& he too was amazed at Mr.B
talk-
entries.summaryText: Sister Annie and DeWitt have lunch with Maggie and George, Mr. S D Porter calls to discuss Bartlett's sermon and Gula's rebellion.

entries.fullText:
This A.M. Dewitt M. left for
home- this is the
first night poor brother
A. has been left alone [?]
stairs-
entries.summaryText: DeWitt leaves for home, leaving A. alone for the first time.

entries.fullText:
Long days - the
heart will stretch
out after the one
gave to return names
entries.summaryText: Mrs. S. at Valapariso- Ind- today

entries.fullText:
Sister Annie, brother
Aaron & self dined on
roast turkey at
Niece Maggie's - the
dinner was good, capitally,
served by both George & Maggie
entries.summaryText: Dinner at Niece Maggie's with Annie, Aaron, George, and Maggie

entries.fullText:
Women Tax payers meeting -
Presented H. R. Selden $100 as a
testimonial -
Letter from Stellman ups
payment of vote- How like a
null time put revolution debt
hangs about my spirit-
entries.summaryText: Women Tax payers meeting and letter from Stellman

entries.fullText:
All these days in the routine
of house work & care- but all saddened
by the continual pressing house of the
fast that dear Gula could be with
is no more- Sister Annie's
children gettng better natured-
and she enjoying her bent
entries.summaryText: Routine house work and sadness over Gula's absence

entries.fullText:
All these days in the routine
of house work & care- but all saddened
by the continual pressing house of the
fast that dear Gula could be with
is no more- Sister Annie's
children gettng better natured-
and she enjoying her bent
entries.summaryText: Routine house work and sadness over Gula's absence

entries.fullText:
Annie
Aaron
Geo. & Maggie
dined at
Sacketts
Annie went
to church-
with Aaron
[?] looked handsomer
entries.summaryText: Dinner at Sacketts with Annie, Aaron, Geo., and Maggie

entries.fullText:
Sister Annie &
niece Maggie & George
went to Hattie Baker
Nirga's to tea & spent
eving very pleasanty-
entries.summaryText: Sister Annie, niece Maggie, and George went to Hattie Baker Nirga's to have tea and spent the evening pleasantly.

entries.fullText:
Thanksgiving- Skaneatles
Sister Annie & self took 7.30
A.M. traian for Skaneatelas - dined
at Cousin A. Lapham's with Cousin
Amy's sons Willie & Joseph & wife-
had delightful visit with Cousins
Amy & Anson & all
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Sister Annie had Thanksgiving in Skaneatles. They had a delightful visit with Cousins Amy and Anson, as well as Amy's sons Willie and Joseph and his wife at Cousin A. Lapham's.

entries.fullText:
Left Skaneatales at 11 A.M.
Home at 6- found that
little Donnie & Susie had
been very good without their [?]
Thanksgiving night Cousin Arson
handed me all my notes & Mrs thru Credit Fornier
those notes all cancelled
$4000~ & said in answer to my attempt to express gratitude he felt
the money well spent- & by his
manner made me feel
his respect for & confidence
in me- & that is
more to me than other
wealth of
the [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony left Skaneatales and returned home. Cousin Arson handed her all her notes, which were all cancelled for $4000, and expressed his respect and confidence in her, which meant more to her than any other wealth.

entries.fullText:
Mother, in attempting to sit
in arm chair, near kitchen window
slipped & fell to floor - but not till
she had staggered & struggled as far
as the table - where Mary [?] found
her - and soon helped her up - her right
knee was only place that showed bruise
entries.summaryText: Mother fell while attempting to sit in an armchair and hurt her knee.

entries.fullText:
am not sure what day it was
but must have been before this-
But from this fall- she has not been
at all well - severe [?] around
her waist - must have wrenched
knee severly
entries.summaryText: Mother has not been well since her fall and is experiencing pain around her waist.

entries.fullText:
Our mother completes her four
scores years today - Had splendid
roast turkey at no 7. - but no sister
Gula at her [?] seat - mother
feeble from severe cold - but at 5
P.M. was able to come down & sit with
us at table. her three girls, Aaron [?]
sister Annie, niece Maggie & George - May
Slocum, Hannah Anthony, [?]
? & Ellen makes - 14 in all
entries.summaryText: Mother turned 80 years old and had a turkey dinner with family, but sister Gula was absent. Mother was feeble due to a severe cold but was able to join the family at the table.

entries.fullText:
Sister Annie & little
Susie D & Dannie left on the
10 P.M. train for Kansas - brother
Eugene went with them - D.R.W
met them at Chicago - How still
the house seemed this night-
the first we had been left to
our own number. Brother A
this one handed me $100 from Sister Gulema
money she had lain away in Bank
- she had told me she meant to give you something
entries.summaryText: Annie, Susie D, and Dannie left for Kansas with Eugene. Brother A gave $100 from Sister Gulema's bank account, which she intended to give to someone.

entries.fullText:
Lecture - Akron - Erie Co. N.Y.
R. S. Talior - sec. Z.M.A.
Left home at 10:20 A.M.
good audience - terrible
gale all day from Levenworth
How still more sad & lonely
our home is to night -
Lorinda Hoay - Charles Clark
nephew of G. W. Clark
entries.summaryText: Susan gave a lecture in Akron, Erie Co. N.Y. to a good audience despite a terrible gale from Levenworth.

entries.fullText:
Lecture - Perry - Wyoming Co. N.Y.
Mr. A Lovejoy -
Charlotte A. Lovejoy - Mrs. Howland
Markham & Walker - good
audience - gave argument
entries.summaryText: Susan gave a lecture in Perry, Wyoming Co. N.Y. to a good audience and presented an argument.

entries.fullText:
Lecture - Mansfield - Pa -
Louisa Lyon Pres. S. P. Beardsley sec'y
W. O. Lewis - (W. W. Bryon -
Lawrenceville &
gave argument-
entries.summaryText: Lecture in Mansfield, Pennsylvania with Louisa Lyon and S. P. Beardsley and others.

entries.fullText:
wrote letters to stock Holder - Women's paper -
& returned $55.- young ladies & gents of the
State Normal school called - also Capt. Pitts
formerly of [?] 7th Ramsay regiment -
The thought of the missing one at
home will come though I am [?]
entries.summaryText: Wrote letters and met with young ladies and gentlemen from the State Normal school and Capt. Pitts in Mansfield, Pennsylvania.

entries.fullText:
Left Mansfield 8 A. M. - pleasant ride
to N. Y. - scenery always fresh & beautiful-
Reached Dr Loziers at 10 P. M. - Mrs Blake
& P.W. Stillman had been waiting & gone -
Letters from Home. Old Ben. Butler refused to
speak for us. already stands committed strongly
he says -
entries.summaryText: Traveled from Mansfield to New York and met with Dr. Loziers, Mrs. Blake, and P.W. Stillman. Received letters from home and learned that Old Ben. Butler refused to speak for them.

entries.fullText:
A. M. - Lozier
No. 6. School Hall -
Small audience but seemed
very attentive - Mrs Lozier went
up with me - the Dr's wife very feeble
2 wives & the 2nd one probable in new year.
entries.summaryText: Spoke at No. 6 School Hall in Yonkers with a small but attentive audience. Mrs. Lozier accompanied her and the doctor's wife was very feeble.

entries.fullText:
Returned to N. Y. - called on
Mrs Phelps - her daughter Sibbie's little girl
died in Florence - scarlet fever - Then
to Mr. E. L. Rease - found her very
feeble - & all interest in life gone - a
most sad spectacle - then
to Cousin Florence Caldwells to Lunch -
entries.summaryText: Returned to New York and visited Mrs. Phelps, learned of the death of her daughter's child in Florence. Visited Mr. E. L. Rease and Cousin Florence Caldwells for lunch.

entries.fullText:
Ct. Woman Suffrage Council meeting
Staid Olympia Browns
last night - her John Henry seems a
a real blessing to her - her home was
delightful - good P. M. meeting and also
evening - though rain poured fairly all day
gave story of my trial -
entries.summaryText: Attended a Connecticut Woman Suffrage Council meeting and stayed with Olympia Browns. Gave a story of her trial and had good meetings despite the rain.

entries.fullText: John Hooker called & I told him what I had refused to write of Mrs. Tilten [?] tell to me. Left New Haven at 121. O. train to Bridgeport. Called at Cooper Institute Bureau has any form. engagements for me. Found letter from sister Mary – Mother a little better – but feeble –
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a phone call with John Hooker and a visit to the Cooper Institute Bureau.

entries.fullText: At Dr. Losiers – rained all day Severe cold 7 feeling misserable Spent two hours in Cooper Union Bur reading room. hints in Boston Tea Party records – Called on Mrs. Phelps – then on May Caldwell Warren – The right eye & right side face [?] moved – she feeling her dissappointment very keenly– our joys from within must [?] her stay & strength
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a visit to Dr. Losiers and Cooper Union Bur, and a visit to Mrs. Phelps and May Caldwell Warren.

entries.fullText: Bright sunshine – first in a long long time Called at Mrs. Sayards – Mrs. Horton at Pauline Wright Davis- Providence today- Heard T. B. Trottingham at Lozier Hall- 6th ave & 20th st. "Ye are not your own, but Lords" who better bought you with his blood- the Two Legends- that of Lucifer & of Christ- it was a splendid elaboration of the thought- none of the old faces to be seen there- dined with Mrs. Blake & called at Abby H. Gibbons- Edward Hopper & wife there from Philadelphia
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a meeting at Lozier Hall and visiting Mrs. Sayards, Pauline Wright Davis, Mrs. Blake, Abby H. Gibbons, and Edward Hopper.

entries.fullText: at Mrs. Loziers- Package letters from home- Mother better- wrote letters to P.W. Davis, A.L.Brown Blackwell & Sister Mary- - at evening called on Mr. Halleck- had good visit- L.Mott & Annie Powell called [?] looking [transcripts?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving letters from home and visiting Mr. Halleck.

entries.fullText: [?] pay like the London [?] Anti Tax-paying meeting- at Union League [?]- 100th Anniversary of Boston Harbor Tea Party- Large meeting- spoke heavily- but friends said forcibly- Mrs Blake did well- Has warm welcome on rising to speak & cordial hand shaky at close- Lib. Brown wnet to meeting-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about attending a meeting at Union League and the 100th Anniversary of Boston Harbor Tea Party.

entries.fullText: [?] [?] So I could not [? ? ? ] Good reports in all papers- World & Herald the best- M.Stillman called to talk of Mary's offer to pay him $ 600- paid his $100. note against me- Mrs Blake called- then I called on Mrs Phillips-- back to tea & to train at 8 P.M. for home-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving good reports in the papers and visiting Mrs. Phillips.

entries.fullText:
Arrived- Rochester at 9:40 A.M.
met Celia Durleigh in Depot -
found sister Mary Luther, son Damin
at No. 7. came on some train from Boston
-found Mother feeble- but less suffering-
called at Hannahs all night - Mary Slocum
still there - then called at Maggies- little
Harry's breathing still bad- over two months
since the attack- feel very uneasy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Rochester and met with Celia Durleigh. She found her sister Mary Luther and son Damin at No. 7. She visited her mother who was feeble but in less pain. She spent the night at Hannah's and visited Mary Slocum and Maggie, where she found little Harry still struggling with his breathing.

entries.fullText:
at home- snow storm but
Warm & melting - Dear Gula
does she look in upon us - does she see &
know us - does she live - shall we all live -
& again come [?] each other & work together
what questions - & get in spite of instinct in
spite of [?] - they will come up
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony stayed at home during a snowstorm and pondered on the existence of Gula and the possibility of all living beings coming together to work.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary & self went
down town - I had pleasant
chat with Judge Selden - he feels
sure he will get both Memorial to
Congress & argument down next month -
& the good angels help him - never seen
him work so hard to breathe.

[*Sister May & May L. went to
Church with Aaron*]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went downtown with her sister Mary and had a pleasant chat with Judge Selden. Her sister May L. and Mary went to church with Aaron.

entries.fullText:
Sister May L. & self dined
at Sister Hannahs - brother
Aaron at niece Maggies - [?]
Mother seemed better - William & May spent evening
All called [?]
down [?] - It does seem
awfully still & lonesome all [?]
Wrote & studied on speech - [?]
of trial while all were gone to church
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had dinner with her sister May L. at Sister Hannah's. Her brother Aaron was at niece Maggie's. Her mother seemed better and William and May spent the evening. She wrote and studied on a speech while everyone was at church.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary L. & self dined
at sister Maggies - then went
down town - Saw Van Vhooris- [?]
despair of getting history of trial published-
- Sister Mary L. is fine appearing warm
Sister Mary & Miss Baker went to Gorswell's Inn
heard lecture-- Mother very much worse - so
come round night - about diapharm
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had lunch with her sister Mary L. at sister Maggie's and then went downtown. She saw Van Vhooris and discussed the despair of getting the history of the trial published. Her sister Mary L. went to Gorswell's Inn to hear a lecture while their mother's condition worsened.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Mary Baker Slocum
left for house - Niece Maggie
went Batavia- - Mary McLean Maxwell - little
Harry spent day at No. 9 & 7 - it is pitiful to
see & hear him breathe so short & rattling - DL
is through trial of [m?] could be made
[?] - but brother Aaron in
faith in anything - Eugene brought my shoes
from Rhoades - making 5 pair again
entries.summaryText: Mary Baker Slocum left for home and niece Maggie went to Batavia. Mary McLean Maxwell and little Harry spent the day at No. 9 & 7. DL finished the trial and Eugene brought Susan B. Anthony's shoes from Rhoades.

entries.fullText:
Left home at 10 A. M. arrived Harrisburg
Penn. at 11 P.M. went Bolton House
awfully tired _
Left Mother very, very feeble & suffering
so much from acute pain with every motion.
& from absolute weakness- I ought not to leave
her - nothing but absolute necessity for money
to keep me above dependence on friends
could drive [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Harrisburg Penn. and expresses concern for her feeble and suffering mother.

entries.fullText:
[Thanksgiving] Christmas _1873
Left Bolton House Harrisburg Penn at 1.30
for Tyrone- weather clear & beautiful
sister Mary L. to leave Rochester
at 10.20 for Kansas - mothers' illness & my
press of work made us all so full of care
as to prevent giving her the time we [?]
reached Clearfield at 9.40 P.M,
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Tyrone and expresses concern for her sister and mother's illnesses.

entries.fullText:
Bright & pleasant
Curwensville _ Clearfield Co, Penn
Mrs C. Arnold- slept Clearfield
on the hardest bed & in noisiest house
I ever knew- A.M. Erwin
& Arnold tries bright young men later [?]
responsibility of course-
Had fine audience- Gave my trial
& its rudiments- all seemed pleased
the first lecture in [?] of Hall
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony gives a lecture in Clearfield and comments on the poor sleeping conditions.

entries.fullText:
Left Gurmensville at noon-
snow falling- Took Gen. Penn.
Pass at 7- had good night sleep
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony leaves Gurmensville and takes a train to an unknown location.

entries.fullText:
arrived Tenafly about 11 A.M.
Snow quite deep- found Theodore
at home- looking very well- Bob .. Mister
left- leg weighted of them to free his [?]
& joint- in woods- hip disease ?
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at Tenafly and visits with Theodore and Bob.

entries.fullText: At- Tenafly-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time in Tenafly.

entries.fullText:
Arrive hotel 2:30 P.M.--
Good audience Gave our argument.
[ha?h] around Power of Ballot a ([Brad? a ????]
Rode home with Antoinette Brown Blackwell
cold ride and cold room. I took some
cold [???tt???]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrives at a hotel in Somerville, NJ and gives an argument to a good audience. She rides home with Antoinette Brown Blackwell and catches a cold.

entries.fullText:
From Antoinettes to South
Branch at 6 P.M. Mary Ann
McLean Pitcher at Depot
Had long talk on[?] Lucy Stones
cried aspersions of Mrs Stanton self-
and her narrow one-sided nature [when?]
Alice then with Antoinette's 5 girls
Found Mary Anns [hopne?] [Henoh?s?]
In[?] [see?] Pitcher very much pleasanter
than I had impression it was
there with niece and [???] 12
years ago this coming June. This is
brother Aarons 61st birthday. The
dinner at Niece Maggie's- No dear
Gula to help celebrate. May & Hannah
cash[?] that from Mothers too feeble
Jerry and Charlie Pitcher at home.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Antoinette's to South Branch and has a long talk about Lucy Stones with Mary Ann McLean Pitcher. She attends a dinner at Niece Maggie's for brother Aaron's 61st birthday.
